@Brin 
assume we have three PGPUs(0000:84:00.0,0000:85:00.0,0000:86:00.0) in one node.
- if case1, then 0000:84:00.0 and 0000:85:00.0 will be configured to nvidia-35, 0000:86:00.0 will be set to nvidia-36.
  case1:
    [gpu_devices]
    enabled_vgpu_types = nvidia-35, nvidia-36

    [vgpu_nvidia-36]
    device_addresses = 0000:86:00.0


- if case2, then the three GPUs will be set to the same type nvidia-35.
  case2:
    [gpu_devices]
    enabled_vgpu_types = nvidia-35, nvidia-36

    [vgpu_nvidia-35]
    device_addresses = 0000:84:00.0

- if case3, then it will be the same results as case2.
  case3:
    [gpu_devices]
    enabled_vgpu_types = nvidia-35, nvidia-36

So to be brief, any devices (that are not specified with a target type) will be configured with the first type in enabled_vgpu_types.

    def _schedule_sg_deletion_maybe(self, sg_id):
        """Schedule possible deletion of the given SG.

        This function must be called when the number of ports
        associated to sg_id drops to zero, as it isn't possible
        to know SG deletions from agents due to RPC API design.

        sec_group = self.sg_port_map.get_or_create_sg(sg_id)

You are right, I was looking at the middle _schedule_sg_deletion_maybe() function but it only triggered by update_security_group_members() and port removal. For an address group, if its members ips drops to zero, the same functions can still remove it. I'll test locally to see if combining sg and ag works and will update the patch if so.

The general reason is I don't want to mess up with the existing logic for handling remote security group IP changes. One case I can think of for the reason of using two set is when address group has duplicate IPs with sg_member_ips, if user delete the IP from address group, the same IP in sg_member_ips can be retained (which it should be). If sharing one set then that will result in an issue.

sg_info['sg_member_ips'] = {'sg_id': {IPs}} if we merge the remote_ag_ips into it, then later when agent calls firewall to update addresses, it won't be able to know either create a local security group object or address group object as the ids in sg_member_ips can be either sg_id or ag_id. See: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/757650/12/neutron/agent/securitygroups_rpc.py#218 and https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/757650/12/neutron/agent/linux/openvswitch_firewall/firewall.py#841. I thought over reusing the SG object for AG in firewall but at least one obstacle I see is for the cleanup flow https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/757650/12/neutron/agent/linux/openvswitch_firewall/firewall.py#851 when a sg has no members or no ports associated with then we trigger the cleanup. But for address group, it never has any port association and we do cleanup only when it has no addresses. So currently I still think we need differentiate sg and ag in firewall thus also needed in sg_info data.

controllerconfig/controllerconfig/upgrad.message: since this was introduced in 2020, the date range 2020-2021 should be provided.

Maybe this fix is OK, but it isn't addressing the root cause. Why would the "kubectl get secret" be failing? Do we have a race condition we need to address? Are there other similar commands in our upgrade migrations that could experience this same problem?
Thanks Andy - please add a bit more to the comment to explain this scenario.

I still don't understand. The command below is just retrieving a secret. This should only require the kube-apiserver and the etcd database. This migration is being run on the activate, so both controllers are up and running and certmon certainly must be running. How could a certmon issue cause the "kubectl get secret" to fail?

> Maybe this fix is OK, but it isn't addressing the root cause. Why would the "kubectl get secret" be failing? Do we have a race condition we need to address? Are there other similar commands in our upgrade migrations that could experience this same problem?

The root cause is in cert-manager. We had this issue a while ago when we were doing similar data extraction from cert-manager in ansible, where cert-manager reports certificate is ready but returns empty data when queried. Sabeel had spent big effort on that and eventually the solution is to retry.

This is the only upgrade script that query data from cert-manager. I'm not aware of other places where similar commands are used.

The problem I had seen was slightly different -- Armada reported app was applied and ready to use, but cert-manager was not usable yet, so we added some extra checks in ansible to create a temporary Issuer and check if everything is ok + added retries and logs to capture details in case of further failures. Since then (last summer/fall), that problem hasn't shown up.

Bin may have seen something similar to what Andy is describing here.

Discussions in the cert-manager community hasn't yielding any firm acknowledgment or fixes, due to its intermittent nature, so adding some retries and resiliency around cert-manager on our platform looks like the best option to me.

It's not cert-mon, but cert-manager we integrated from upstream. cert-mon is not involved here. The secrets (the tls.crt and tls.key) we are querying here are created/updated by cert-manager (on line101). Then we wait on line 107, up to 30s x 3 times, for the certificate secret to be ready. Once the readiness check passes, we start to extract the secret but still intermittently it returns empty data. (David observed it only once in VBox deployment).

We had this issue before and the solution is to wait a bit and retry. Similar code is in dcmanager subcloud_manager.py (around line 155 in _create_intermediate_ca_cert()).

import cryptography means that python-cryptography "should" be in a spec file as a Requires for controllerconfig.   In the past we have gotten lucky because something else we install has it, but if we ever clean those other modules, we can get broken.

In terms of tox impact,  openstack-armada-app/python-k8sapp-openstack/k8sapp_openstack/tox.ini  references controllerconfig in its tox.ini file, which means it "could" fail if it imported these files, but I do not believe that even in that situation it will fail because it also includes sysinv, which has cryptography declared in its requirements.txt file.

Would prefer that these imports were in order, but we are not doing this for 10 other scripts, and the tox.ini is explicitly allowing H306 (imports alphabetical order)  so I'm not going to block this review on making that change

distributedcloud/dcmanager/audit/subclou.message:
There's one caveat with doing it this way...if there are multiple subclouds that came online in the same audit cycle we'll end up querying the region one data multiple times.

An alternative would be to store the patch audit and firmware audit data in class variables so that they'd be available while auditing other subclouds that have also gone from offline to online.  Do we want to go that route instead?
Also - we only do the additional audits when the subcloud is managed (I think) so we need to account for that.

As noted, to optimize, class variable to cache the RegionOne data on a per batch-basis should be ok. i.e. for a batch of subclouds upon entry to SubcloudAuditWorkerManager::audit_subclouds(), and cleared on exit, so that RegionOne wouldn't need to be queried again during a batch.   (The cache would be close to the decision when the audit batch was started and as noted also, the audit interval is much larger than batch audit cycle).

My thought was that you wouldn't do this handling here, but instead would do it in the SubcloudManager.update_subcloud_availability method when it handles the RPC setting the availability_status to online. That avoids the multiple queries, because the audits will be handled by the next audit loop.
I had suggested doing this in dcmanager-manager where we trigger the cert-mon audit (due to going online). What was the reason for putting it here?
Saving the latency of a couple of RPC calls.  In any case, I've moved it to dcmanager-manager to match the call that we do when going managed.

Also, an argument could be made that whether or not we'll run the subaudits when online but unmanaged is an implementation detail of the audit subsystem, and dcmanager shouldn't care about that. :)
That makes sense - best to keep the knowledge in the audit subsystem.

glance/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message:
I think there was some question about how this gets set or incremented or something, so most of the below are notes for myself on how this works, in case anyone else is fuzzy on it. Looks like we only set this when the task fails or succeeds:

http://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/2c893fbd80d0241fad2515221b61266ced12f92d/glance/domain/__init__.py#L437-L437

further supported by:

http://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/2c893fbd80d0241fad2515221b61266ced12f92d/glance/domain/__init__.py#L472-L474

and that TTL comes from now+CONF at the time of task object instantiation:

http://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/2c893fbd80d0241fad2515221b61266ced12f92d/glance/domain/__init__.py#L373-L376

All of that seems fine, except that presumably we could have some tasks that get created and then never actually change state, such as  would be the case if we start an import and then power off the worker node.

Looks like the task scrub would also never clean up these things because they would have no expires_at:

http://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/2c893fbd80d0241fad2515221b61266ced12f92d/glance/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L1672-L1684

Now, that's an existing problem that we have today, so nothing new. However, exposing this to users means that more people might notice and/or be confused by it. It seems clear, however, that we should at *least* be calling _task_soft_delete() in this method to make sure that legit complete/failed tasks *do* get scrubbed, or just use task_get_all() internally here with our own set of crafted filters.

However, I also wonder if it might be good to also add a filter of:

 query.filter(updated_at <= (timeutils.utcnow() + 
                             CONF.task_time_to_live))

We could also double the CONF value just to make sure there's plenty of time for it to continue being acted upon, but so that we will eventually stop showing those tasks to the user.
Using _task_soft_delete instead of calling task_get_all and I also liked the suggestion of using additional filter.
Yeah, I think this makes sense. As mentioned before, I can see doubling the time period for this belt-and-suspenders check, but I expect the default is so long that it would basically never matter.

I think this is fine.  At 1669, expired tasks in a final state are deleted, and here we make sure that old tasks that were in suspension don't clog up the display and confuse the user, but they'll still be available to the admin for troubleshooting purposes.
Also just noticed, this does not seem to be used. Assume we can drop it?
Is this redundant, given the check for is_task_visible() below?
Er, I just realized this isn't tested directly. I thought I pointed that out earlier, but don't see it so gerrit must have eaten it.
Sad to say but we have 0 coverage for this file, may be because for unit tests we are using db/simple/api.py

I guess this could be an operator configuration bug depending on how you look at it.

If an operator forgot to give someone the `admin` role on the system and that person is still using an admin project-scoped token to do something, they'll hit this. In that case, the operator should probably update the authorization for that user.

deployment/ovn/ovn-controller-container-.message:
Won't this always be the case if we're on RHEL7, so we could move the subsequent tasks into a block after line 340-348 (Gather missing facts) which only runs on the same conditions as lines 358/359.

In fact it should probably be after the step 0 block which does the hybrid state switch just to ensure that it's more intuitively ordered in this file.

This can be done quicker in a single task, and will be properly idempotent too:

- name: If ovn controller is present, drain it and exit it
  shell: |-
    set -o pipefail
    exit_code=0
    if docker ps | grep ovn_controller; then
      docker update --restart=no ovn_controller
      docker exec -u root ovn_controller bash -c "if [ -f /usr/bin/ovn-appctl ] ; then ovn-appctl -t ovn-controller exit ; else ovs-appctl -t ovn-controller exit ; fi"
      exit_code=3
    fi
    exit ${exit_code}
  register: _ovn_container_stop
  changed_when: _ovn_container_stop.rc == 3
  failed_when: _ovn_container_stop.rc not in [0,3]

"OVNClient.disassociate_floatingip" is called from "OVNL3RouterPlugin.disassociate_floatingips", that is called from "ML2plugin.delete_port".

About "OVNClient._delete_floatingip", this is in charge of deleting the OVN FIP references; the QoS plugin method is in charge of deleting the QoS registers. Both methods have different goals.

NOTE: maybe the QoS plugin should have been implemented using subscriptions to events (delete port, update network, etc). The way it was implemented, being called synchronously from the OVN client is not the most elegant one. But you need to remember the goal of QoS plugin is to abstract any OVN QoS operation.
Right, this could be a good option. But I'll keep the same OVN client terms: when a FIP is disassociated in Neutron, is deleted in OVN.

+1, I agree not to fail the whole interface attach operation due to this error

sure but then you create a potential race condition where the Neutron event could fail and then the metadata information would be unreliable.

I'd prefer (if possible) to populate again the metadata information of the guest once we get the successful event back from Neutron.

after discussing it on IRC [1], we went on a consensus that it's acceptable to remove the VIF from the metadata since the NIC on the VM already detached, even if the Neutron action could potentially fail.

Neverming this concern, then.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2021-02-04.log.html#t2021-02-04T16:14:18
I'd have preferred you provide a separate helper method for updating the guest metadata before writing it, instead of touching the existing read-only one which is then now tainting the result.

This function simply generates metadata from the instance object with no side effects. guest.set_metadata is responsible for the actual writing.

Also, the existing metadata will be completely overwritten by the new metadata, but this is limited to the nova-specific XML Namespace, so I believe it will not conflict with other systems (such as user defined metadata).

If refactoring is needed, could you pinpoint the statements for me?

tobiko/openstack/heat/_stack.py.message:
I really think we should remove this, 
if a stack is created really fast or deleted really fast, 
then our api heat stack.stack_status poll will "jump" right to 
"creation_complete" (skip "in_progress") 
in that case this loop will hang no ? 

I think we should switch to : 
while stack and stack.stack_status not in expected_status:

This way we avoid that situation.

WDYT ?

I think the while condition is correct as it is now.

If the stack_status jumps immediately to creation_complete, the loop ends because that is one of the expected_status. This is correct, it does not hang.

If we removed the "and stack.stack_status.endswith('_IN_PROGRESS')" condition and the creation/deletion failed (CREATE_FAILED or DELETE_FAILED), the loop would hang.

kuryr_kubernetes/controller/handlers/kur.message: wondering if we should return resourceNotReady here instead to ensure the prepopulation happens once the status is filled in
We should, on_added will only be triggered once, so we won't get this again like on_present.
really? I thought the resourceNotReady would allow other handlers to progress and then eventually the action would be retried. But it seems I remember wrong! :)

if we use KuryrNetworkPopulationHandler handles before the kuryrnetworkhandler the KuryrNetworkPopulationHandler would keep raising resourcenotready all the time causing a controller restart, and only then the other event for kuryrnetworkhandler would fill the status.
In order to avoid this I'm now skipping the event and letting it be retried once again during any patching crd operation.
I started wondering the same when testing it ;)
as we are now reacting on "on_present" instead of "on_added", perhaps worth to check if already populated first (not a big deal though!)

roles/ara_api/vars/RedHat.yaml.message:
This is coming from software collections which requires a bit more work than just listing the package here:
https://www.softwarecollections.org/en/scls/rhscl/rh-python36/

If we are going to support running the API server on top of EL7, I would rather we do it through the python36 interpreter in EPEL rather than software collections.

This has the added benefit of having the python3 interpreter at /usr/bin/python3 instead of /opt/rh/rh-python36/root/usr/bin/python3.

So this would mean that we need to install epel-release and then install the "python36" package. It doesn't seem that we need to install a virtualenv package, it is built into the interpreter.

The role is currently designed to pull psycopg2 with pip: https://github.com/ansible-community/ara/blob/bae32bf42565acd7749c235eab37ae4598d43925/roles/ara_api/tasks/database_engine/django.db.backends.postgresql.yaml#L38-L43

I suppose it would eventually be nice to support installation from packages but we're not there yet.

When testing locally with EPEL, this is what I needed to run in order to be able to install psycopg2 from pypi:

    yum install -y epel-release postgresql postgresql-devel gcc
    yum install -y python36 python36-devel
    python3 -m venv /tmp/test
    /tmp/test/bin/pip install psycopg2
